1.1. Basic Principles of Photoelectrochemical Water Splitting
sections.text:
Rapid increase of global population has resulted in an evergrowing demand for energy. Seeking sustainable energy sources is becoming an emergent issue.[1] Hydrogen gas, with high gravimetric energy density (≈140 MJ kg−1) and zero carbon emission has been regarded as an encouraging and potential energy carrier to replace the conventional fossil fuels. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting is a promising and environmentally friendly method to obtain hydrogen gas in a sustainable manner.[2] Basically, PEC devices convert solar energy into chemical energy that stored in the form of dihydrogen molecules.[2b,e,3] The first report of a PEC cell for water splitting dates back to 1972.[3c] A conventional PEC cell is composed of at least one photoelectrode responsible for harvesting
Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting represents an environmentally friendly and sustainable method to obtain hydrogen fuel. Semiconductor materials as the central components in PEC water splitting cells have decisive influences on the device’s solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency. Among semiconductors, metal oxides have received a lot of attention due to their outstanding (photo)-electrochemical stability, low cost, favorable band edge positions and wide distribution of bandgaps. In the past decades, significant processes have been made in developing metal oxide nanomaterials for PEC water splitting. In this review, the recent progress using metal oxides as photoelectrodes and co-catalysts for PEC water splitting is summarized. Their performance, limitations and potentials are also discussed. Last, the key challenges and opportunities in the development and implementation of metal oxide nanomaterials for PEC water splitting are discussed.

Figure 1 illustrates the basic architecture of a single chamber PEC water splitting cell, including an n-type semiconductor photoanode and a metal cathode that are immersed in an electrolyte and connected by electric wire.[2b,4] Under light irradiation, electrons in the semiconductor photoelectrode are excited and promoted from the valence band (VB) to the unoccupied conduction band (CB). While a large portion of the generated electrons and holes recombine with each other momentarily, part of the generated electrons are able to transport to the cathode surface and reduce protons (dissociated from water molecules) to hydrogen gas (H2), and some holes migrate to the photoanode surface where water is oxidized to oxygen gas (O2).[2a,f ] When the
photoelectrode is contacted with electrolyte, charge transfer between the semiconductor and the electrolyte induces the formation of upward (photoanode) or downward (photocathode) band bending, which can facilitate the separation of photoinduced electrons and holes to tamper the undesired recombination.[5] Therefore, it is favorable to use n-type and p-type semiconductors as photoanode and photocathode candidates, respectively. To meet this requirement, the photoelectrodes must absorb light with photon energy equal to or larger than 1.23 eV.[5c] In fact, the photon energy should be much larger than this theoretical value due to the energy loss, such as voltage loss at electrode/ wire contacts and energy loss induced by overpotential.[2b,5a,c,6] To achieve spontaneous solar-driven water splitting, the selection of semiconductor materials for light absorption is of central importance for PEC studies.

diffusion to electrode surface, and 3) charge injection into electrolyte to oxidize or reduce water (Figure 2a).[7] Light absorption capability determines the number of electron-hole pairs that are generated by light, and reflects the efficiency of sunlight utilization. Charge separation and diffusion processes are associated with how many electrons and holes can reach the semiconductor surface. On their way to the surface, a portion of the electrons and holes are lost due to electron-hole recombination. Charge injection step is referred to the process that the amount of electrons and holes reaching the electrode surface can successfully trigger water splitting reactions. An ideal photoelectrode should meet the following requirements to achieve efficient PEC water splitting. First, the CB edge potential of the photoelectrode material should be lower than the H2 evolution potential, while the VB edge should be higher than the O2 evolution potential, as shown in Figure 2b.[5a,8] It means that the band gap energy required to spontaneously split water should be larger than 1.23 eV, in order to compensate the overpotentials of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and energy loss at electrode/wire contact.[2b,6b,c] Yet, photoelectrodes are also required to have strong absorption across solar spectrum to generate a large population of photo-excited electron-hole pairs. Large bandgap semiconductors with limited light absorption in visible light region, though they may have suitable band edge positions, are not favorable. Moreover, efficient charge separation and transport in semiconductors are also critical for PEC performance. Rapid separation of electrons and holes reduces electron-hole recombination loss and increases the yield of photo-excited electrons and holes for water splitting. Finally, the semiconductor materials for photoelectrodes should be inexpensive and photochemically robust against oxidative and reductive conditions during the water splitting process.[3a,5a,6a,9] For example, n-type silicon and metal chalcogenides have suitable bandgaps for visible light absorption but they suffer from oxidative corrosion.

sections.heading: 1.3. Metal Oxides for PEC Water Splitting
sections.text:
Among the commonly used semiconductors for photoelectrodes, metal oxides attract a lot of attention due to their excellent chemical stability, suitable band edge positions, low cost and tunable bandgaps.[10] Oxide is usually one of the most stable forms of metal compounds in nature and can be easily synthesized. Moreover, metal oxides have a wide distribution of the bandgap and band edge positions, as shown in Figure 3a. Typically, the VB and CB of metal oxides possess O 2p character and transition metal (s, d or p) character, respectively.[11]

The high ionic character of O 2p and metal s orbital renders metal oxides such as ZnO (3.4 eV), Ga2O3 (4.5 eV) and Al2O3 (8.8 eV) their large bandgaps. Metal oxides containing transition metal cations with dn electronic configurations, such as Fe2O3 (d5, 2.2 eV) and Cu2O (d10, 2.1 eV), have narrower bandgaps that enable visible light absorption (Figure 3b). Metal oxides such as PbO (2.1 eV) involving post-transition metal cations with high binding energy s states, O 2p and metal p characters have even smaller bandgap (Figure 3b). Additionally, the bandgap and band edge positions of metal oxides can be tailored by combining two metal cations to form ternary oxides. For example, BiVO4 has a bandgap of 2.3 eV with the conduction band edge close to 0 V vs RHE, owing to the overlap of empty Bi 6p orbitals with antibonding V 3d-O 2p states.[10] Moreover, most transition metal oxides are either intrinsic ntype or p-type semiconductors due to the presence of defects. For example, TiO2, ZnO, Fe2O3 and WO3 typically exhibit ntype properties and can be used as photoanodes, whilst NiO, Cu2O and CuO have p-type character as photocathodes. Their electronic properties can also be tuned through complementary n- and p-type doping.[6a,12] Furthermore, metal oxides can also be used as electrochemical co-catalysts for water splitting. NiO, Co3O4, RuO2 and IrOx have been demonstrated to be efficient OER catalysts.[13] They can couple with photoanodes for facilitating PEC water oxidation reaction kinetics. In all, the rich diversity of metal oxides with multi-functions offers a lot of opportunities to develop high performance PEC systems.

sections.heading: 1.4. Intrinsic Limitations of Metal Oxides for PEC Water Splitting and Current Solutions
sections.text:
Although metal oxides are promising materials for PEC water splitting, they have their own intrinsic limitations. For instance, wide bandgap metal oxides such as ZnO and TiO2 have limited light absorption in the visible and infra-red regions of the solar spectrum. Fe2O3 has favorable bandgap for visible light absorption but it suffers from sluggish photo-generated carrier transport and extraction, due to the slow polaron hopping leading to limited electrical conductivity.[11] The large electrical resistivity of most metal oxides also consumes a large amount of energy and poses significant internal potential drop, both of
which contribute overpotential and are detrimental to PEC performance.[14]
A variety of strategies have been developed to address the aforementioned drawbacks of metal oxide photoelectrodes for PEC water splitting. Compared to their bulk counterparts, nanostructured materials with smaller size and larger interfacial surface area can effectively shorten the diffusion distance for photo-excited charge carriers and facilitate the electronhole separation at the electrode/electrolyte interface, and thus improve charge collection and utilization efficiency. Therefore, nanostructured photoelectrodes typically exhibit outstanding photoactivity.[3b,5a,15] Nanostructured metal oxides, including
WO3,[16] ZnO,[12b,17] Fe2O3,[12c,14a,18] TiO2,[3a,b,9,15c,19] BiVO4[20] and Cu2O,[21] have been extensively explored for PEC water splitting. In addition to homogeneous metal oxide, rational integrations of multiple metal oxides into heterostructures have proven to be effective in facilitating the separation of photoinduced electron-hole pairs and maximize light absorption. Combining BiVO4 and WO3 to form type II heterojunction not only facilitates its charge separation, but also expands its light absorption capability of the composite photoelectrode.[20a,22] Moreover, the optical and electrical properties of metal oxides can be improved by doping, either through addition of extrinsic dopants (or impurities) or creation of intrinsic defects. Doping can introduce impurity energy states within the band structure to narrow bandgap and modify electronic properties. One typical example is that the electrical conductivity of TiO2 can be substantially improved by creating oxygen vacancies, which serve as electron donors.[15c] Finally, the sluggish water splitting kinetics of many photoelectrodes can be improved through surface decoration of metal oxide based water splitting co-catalysts. These co-catalysts enhance the transfer of photo-induced carriers for water oxidation and/or reduction.[23] In this review, we summarize the recent progress using nanostructured metal oxides as photoelectrodes and co-catalysts for PEC water splitting. The limitations of commonly used metal oxide photoanodes and photocathodes for PEC water splitting as well as the strategies developed to address them will be thoroughly discussed. In the end, we will provide a brief outlook of the current challenges and future opportunities of metal oxide photoelectrodes for PEC water splitting.

2.1. Wide Band-Gap Metal Oxides
sections.text:
Wide bandgap metal oxides such as TiO2, ZnO and SrTiO3 have been extensively studied as photoanode materials for PEC water oxidation.[12b,16b,17a,19d,24] While these wide bandgap materials have bandgap between 3.0 and 3.4 eV that is not optimal for light harvesting, they have favorable band edge positions straddling the water electrolysis potentials. Moreover, these wide bandgap semiconductors also suffer from other

For example, TiO2 has hole diffusion length of only ≈10 nm that would increase the recombination possibility and thus limit water oxidation performance.[25] Low dimensional materials with large surface area and short hole diffusion pathway provide new opportunities to address this issue. In the past decades, a number of zero-dimensional (0D), one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D) and threedimensional (3D) metal oxide nanostructures have been fabricated.[5a,15a–d,24a,h–j,26] These nanostructured wide bandgap metal oxides exhibit enhanced PEC performance, compared to their bulk counterparts.[26c,27] Nevertheless, these metal oxides still have other unfavorable properties, such as limited visible light absorption and (photo-)electrochemical instability. In this section, we will present recently developed strategies on how to address these problems through rational chemical modifications.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Approaches to Increase Visible Light Photoactivity
sections.text:
Wide band gap metal oxide semiconductors are limited by their narrow light absorption range in only the UV region, which represents only 3–5% of the total solar energy. Various strategies therefore have been developed to expand their light absorption to visible light that accounts for 42–43% of total solar energy.[28] One common strategy is to modify the band structures of metal oxides by element doping. Element doping can introduce impurity states within the bandgap and thus narrow the band gaps of metal oxides (Figure 4a). Reduction
in bandgap red shifts their absorption. Elements such as C, N, S, V, B, W, and Sn have been used to dope wide bandgap metal oxides. These doped metal oxides showed enhanced absorption and improved photoactivity.[12b,19d,24g,26a,29] Doping can be introduced into metal oxides in numerous ways. The most commonly used method is to mix dopant precursors together with metal oxide synthetic precursors.[12c,30] Alternatively, doped metal oxides can be obtained by annealing pristine metal oxides in the presence of dopant containing vapor. For instance, N dopants can be incorporated into TiO2 and ZnO by annealing metal oxides in ammonia gas at elevated temperatures.[3a,12b] Although these doping methods are facile and effective; it is difficult for them to quantitatively control the doping concentration. Recently, Wang et al. reported the synthesis of N-doped TiO2 nanowire arrays by an ion implantation method.[31] Comparing to other doping approaches, ion implantation does not involve any element other than the doping element which offers a quantitative way to introduce the selected element. N-implanted TiO2 exhibits bright yellow color, suggesting the optical properties of TiO2 are altered (Figure 4b). With the help of OER co-catalysts, the incident photon to current conversion efficiency (IPCE) of N-TiO2 reached 17% at 450 nm, representing the best value reported for the TiO2 based photoelectrodes to date.[31] Besides monodoping, TiO2 co-doped with two or more elements has been reported.[32] For example, Yang et al. doped TiO2 nanostructures with S and oxygen vacancies via aluminum reduction followed by annealing in H2S atmosphere. The co-doped TiO2 exhibited superior visible light absorption, compared to their mono-doped counterparts (S-doped TiO2 and oxygen deficient TiO2). The enhancement is attributed to the synergistic effect between S and oxygen vacancies, by simultaneously improving visible light absorption and charge collection efficiency.[32] The molten Al reduction creates a high level of Ti3+ in the TiO2, which could significantly improve the electrical conductivity of TiO2 and facilitate the charge separation at the semiconductor/electrolyte interface. Meanwhile, the S doping and Ti3+ also create a series of impurity states in the band structure of TiO2 that can extend the light absorption from UV region to visible and even near IR region. Therefore, the TiO2 sample co-doped with Ti3+ and sulfur could have simultaneously improved electrical properties and light absorption capability. Similar synergistic effect was also observed between Ti3+ and N dopant for improving PEC performance of TiO2 nanowires.[30]

Theoretical calculations have been performed to simulate the electronic band structures of element doped metal oxides and to study the effects of dopants on the optical properties of metal oxides.[29f,33] More importantly, theoretical calculation and prediction provide guidance for experimental studies. Asahi et al. used first-principle calculation to understand the evolution of electronic band structure of TiO2 with the incorporation of various anodic dopants.[29f ] Figure 5a shows the calculated density of states (DOS) of TiO2 doped with C, N, F, P and S.[29f ] Among the DOS curves, the substitutional N and S dopants are most effective in bandgap narrowing. The states of P and C dopants are too deep in the band structure, which cannot overlap sufficiently with the band states of TiO2. Additionally, considering the S ionic radius is larger than N, the incorporation of N doping is believed to be easier than S doping. The parallel experimental studies also verify their prediction that N doped TiO2 has an improved photocatalytic activity under visible light region (<500 nm). Gai et al. calculated the doping TiO2 with 3d and 4d transition metal ions and the obtained DOS curves of TiO2 doped with V, Cr, Nb and Mo as shown in Figure 5b.[33a] When transition metals are substitutionally doped into TiO2, the largest perturbation occurs at the conduction band minimum. V and Cr doping create deeper donor levels than those of Mo and Nb doping, which effectively narrow the bandgap of TiO2 and improve its visible light absorption. However, the localized V and Cr states may work as recombination centers and decrease the photoactivity of TiO2. On contrary, the 4d orbital energies of Nb and Mo are close to or higher than those of Ti 3d orbitals, and thus the dopant states are resonant with the conduction band. Unfortunately, mono-doping Mo and Nb have minor effect on narrowing the bandgap of TiO2. In this regard, co-doped TiO2 with metal and non-metal ions were theoretically studied and the calculated DOS curves are displayed in Figure 5c.[33a] Interestingly, co-doping with Nb/N and Mo/N both show narrowed bandgap of TiO2 with minimum perturbation in conduction of TiO2. Nevertheless, the bandgap narrowing by Nb/N co-doping is less than 0.4 eV, which is too small for improving the visible light absorption of TiO2. On the other hand, Mo/C co-doping can reduce the bandgap by about 1.1 eV and considerably enhance the visible light absorption of TiO2 and its efficiency for PEC water splitting. In addition, the electrical properties of the co-doped system may also need to be further improved for achieving even better photocatalytic performance.
Furthermore, plasmonic metal nanoparticles such as Au, Ag, and Cu have been employed to broaden light absorption for wide bandgap photoelectrodes.[2g,35] The significantly broadened and enhanced light absorption are attributed to several mechanisms: surface plasma resonance (SPR) induced hot electron injection, near filed electromagnetic induced electron-hole generation and improved light scattering. It is well accepted that hot electrons under SPR excitation can inject into the conduction band of metal oxide, and thus, obtain visible light photoactivity (Figure 6a).[2d,g,24e,f,36] Pu et al. demonstrated that the photoactivity of TiO2 nanowires can be extended to cover the entire visible light region by decorating TiO2 with gold nanoparticles (NPs) and nanorods with different sizes (Figure 6b).[24f ] Although plasmonic metal NPs showed promising effect in enhancing the visible light photoactivity of wide bandgap semiconductors, the overall photoelectric conversion efficiency in visible light and near infra-red regions is still low because of the extremely short lifetime of hot electrons (1–2 ps) of metal NPs. The ultrashort lifetime of hot-electrons impedes the charge injection from metal NPs to semiconductor.[37] Improving the harvesting efficiency of hot electrons is the key to boost the plasmon enhanced visible light photoactivity of wide band metal oxides.
Another strategy to broaden the absorption width for wide band metal oxides is to sensitize them with smallband gap semiconductors such as quantum dots and dye molecules.[3a,17a,24d,38] Typically, sensitizers and metal oxides form type II-junctions that are beneficial for separation of photoexcited charge carriers.[17a] The PEC performance of sensitized photoanodes depends on both the band gap of sensitizer and metal oxide, as well as the interfacial charge transfer
efficiency.[39] For example, Wang et al. designed a double-sided ZnO nanowire photoanode co-sensitized with CdS and CdSe quantum dots.[17a] This unique photoanode structure exhibited significant visible light photoactivity of up to 700 nm and achieved a photocurrent density as high as 12 mA cm−2 at 0.4 V vs Ag/AgCl (with Na2S as a hole sacrificial agent). Despite the enhanced visible light absorption, these quantum dot-decorated photoanodes often suffer from severe photocorrosion. In addition, the toxicity of Cd-based chalcogenides causes serious environmental safety issues and negatively impacts their mass production.[39c]

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Approaches to Improve Electronic Properties
sections.text:
Poor electrical conductivity of wide bandgap metal oxide semiconductors is another major hindrance that causes a significant loss of electron-hole pairs due to recombination and negatively affects their photoactivity.[40] Doping is the most effective strategy to improve electrical conductivity by modifying electronic band structures.[41] For instance, Yang et al. observed significantly increased donor densities in ZnO nanowires by nitrogen doping. Recently, controllable creation of intrinsic defects is emerging as a promising method for improving the electronic properties of metal oxide semiconductors.[15c,24i,30,42] Wang et al. reported a hydrogen treatment method to introduce oxygen vacancies in TiO2 nanowire arrays. Oxygen vacancies serve as shallow donors that can substantially increase the carrier density of TiO2 by orders of magnitudes (Figure 7a).[15c] Increasing the donor densities improves the charge separation efficiency and reduces energy loss in the TiO2 nanowire (NW) arrayed photoanodes. The photocurrent densities of the hydrogen treated TiO2 (H-TiO2) NWs at the temperature range from 300 to 450 °C are consistently higher than the untreated TiO2 NWs. Moreover, the optimal hydrogen treatment temperature was determined to be 350 °C (Figure 7b). With the hydrogen annealing temperature increasing, the color of TiO2 films changed from white to pale yellow, gray and finally black, indicating the optical property of TiO2 was modified. Interestingly, IPCE studies revealed that the photoactivity of H-TiO2 in visible light region was still negligibly small, suggesting the photocurrent enhancement is not due to the increased visible light absorption (Figure 7c). Transient absorption (TA) mechanistic studies provided strong evidence that the improved electrical conductivity of H-TiO2 was responsible for efficient spatial separation of electron-hole pairs on the sub-microsecond time scale at moderate applied bias. In addition, it effectively suppressed microsecond to seconds charge carrier recombination, which was believed to be the primary factor behind the dramatically improved PEC activity (Figure 7d).[43]

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Long Term Stability
sections.text:
Photostability is another important property for photoelectrodes. Among the wide bandgap metal oxides, TiO2 is believed to be one of the most stable photoanode materials for water oxidation. Although doping and defect engineering have proved to be effective in promoting the PEC performance of TiO2, their potential effect on the long-term stability has been a concern. Recently, Yang et al. investigated the long-term photostability of pristine TiO2 (rutile, anatase and mixed phased TiO2) and hydrogen-treated TiO2 photoanodes.[24j] They found that hydrogen-treated TiO2 was equally stable as the pristine samples, indicating controlled introduction of oxygen vacancies does not necessarily affect the photostability of TiO2. Yet, they surprisingly found that all TiO2 photoanodes indeed suffered
from photohole induced photocorrosion (Figure 8a).[24j] TiO2 electrodes exhibited obvious morphology change after the long term stability test (Figure 8b),[24j] including decreased nanowire length and amorphorized nanowire surface. Importantly, the authors also demonstrated two strategies to suppress the photocorrosion. The first approach was to modify the TiO2 with co-catalyst and add urea as sacrificial hole accepter in electrolyte to facilitate hole transfer. The second approach was to coat an amorphous Ti(OH)4 layer shell on TiO2 nanowire arrays to avoid direct contact between electrolyte solution.[24j] Both approaches can stablize the photocurrent for at least 72 h under light illumination (Figure 8c,d). ZnO is another wide band gap semiconductor that suffers from severe photocorrosion and chemical corrosion during PEC water oxidation process.[12b,17b,45] Adding hole sacrificial reagent is also an efficient way to suppress the photocorrosion of ZnO photoanode. However, most of hole sacrificial reagents are important chemical fuels such as methanol.[41,46] Thus it is not desirable for using sacrificial reagents for practial applications. To improve the photoelectrochemical stability of ZnO remains a technical challenge.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. BiVO4
sections.text:
BiVO4 is a direct band gap semiconductor with a favorable band gap of 2.3–2.5 eV, which enables the material to absorb sunlight up to 530 nm. Additionally, because of the overlap of empty Bi 6p orbitals with antibonding V 3d–O 2p states, the conduction
band of BiVO4 is very close to 0 V vs RHE at pH = 0, making it a promising photoanode for water oxidation.[11,48] However, inefficient charge transport and interfacial charge transfer properties are the key limiting factors for BiVO4 photoanodes. Numerous methods have been explored to address these limitations. sections.text:

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Other Metal Oxides
sections.text:
The recent advance in development of multi-nary metal oxides opens up new opportunities for PEC water oxidation.[68] Similar to BiVO4, a number of other metal oxides with AMO4 structures, where A is a big electropostive ion and M is a smaller cation with a high oxidation state such as W, Mo and V were also developed as photocatalysts.[69] For example, Yao et al. used Mo to partially replace V in BiVO4 and prepared BiV0.98Mo0.02O4 compound with a bandgap of 2.39 eV, which showed excellent performance in photo-degradation of methylene blue under visible light irradiation.[70] Additionally, CuWO4 also has similar structure with an indirect band gap of 2.25 eV, which can extend the light absorption to 550 nm. Meanwhile, CuWO4 has better photostability compared to WO3.[68b–d] However, the main limitations of CuWO4 are its poor conductivity and rapid
electron-hole recombination at the CuWO4 electrode/electrolyte interface.[71] Other metal tungstates composed of the closed shell divalent cations including Sr, Ca, Mg and Zn, have band gap energies greater than 3 eV, which can only harvest ultraviolet light in the solar spectrum.[68c]
Perovskite structures (ABO3) and perovskite-related structures and spinels structures (AB2O4) are other important classes of multi-nary metal oxides that have been extensively studied as photocatalysts.[69] For instance, the ferrite family such as BiFeO3, BaFeO3 and SrFeO3 have typical perovskite structures and have been found to have photocatalytic performance for water splitting and degradation reactions.[7,69,72] Moreover, perovskite-type solid solutions have been developed to modulate the bandgaps of perovskite metal oxides. For example, Wang et al. developed a solid solution perovskite (Ag0.75Sr0.25) (Nb0.75Ti0.25)O3 with a bandgap of 2.8 eV, which is smaller than SrTiO3 but larger than AgNbO3.[73] The perovskite-type solid solution exhibited visible light photoactivity for decomposition of acetaldehyde.[73] Similarly, Qiu et al. also developed solidsolution perovskite Cu(II)-(Sr1−yNay)(Ti1−xMox)O3 to extend the metal oxides to visible light region and used them as visible light photocatalysts for the decomposition of 2-propanol.[74] Additionally, layered bismuth based oxyhalides such as BiOCl, BiOI and BiOBr were also found have reasonable photoactivity in the visible light range.[75] Previous studies have primarily focused on the synthesis and implementation of these multinary metal oxides as powder-based photocatalysts for photocatalytic water splitting or organic molecule decomposition, which are beyond the scope of this review. The results and recent progress of multi-nary metal oxide based photocatalysts have been well summarized and discussed in a number of excellent review articles.[7,69,72,76]

sections.heading: 3.1. Cu2O and CuO
sections.text:
Cuprous oxide (Cu2O), a p-type semiconductor with a direct bandgap of 2.0 eV, is an attractive oxide for photoelectrochemical hydrogen production.[21c,d,77] Moreover, the conduction band and valence band of Cu2O can well straddle the water oxidation and hydrogen evolution potentials, making it promising for sustainable PEC water splitting.[77b] Furthermore, the suitable bandgap of 2.0 eV could theoretically deliver a photocurrent of 14.7 mA cm−2 and a solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency of 18% based on the AM 1.5 standard spectrum.[21a] However, the main limitation for the use of Cu2O as a photocathode for water reduction is its poor electrochemical stability in aqueous solutions. The reduction potential of CuI to Cu0 is located 0.47 eV, which lies in the potential range of water spitting, resulting in its poor stability during water splitting. Recently, several methods and techniques have been developed to solve this issue, such as surface passivation[21d] and atomic layer deposition (ALD).[78] To date, ALD is the most effective way for deposition of ultrathin film on nanostructured surfaces at low temperatures with good control over thickness and composition at the angstrom scale.[21a] Paracchino et al. used electrodeposited method to successfully synthesize Cu2O films. Cu2O grains were covered with ALD coated metal oxide protective layers [5 × (4 nm ZnO/0.17 nm Al2O3)/11 nm TiO2], and finally decorated with Pt nanoparticles (Figure 12a).[21a] The protected Cu2O showed a compact and uniform surface (Figure 12b), indicating the outstanding quality of films coated by ALD. Significantly, the protected Cu2O photocathode exhibited substantially improved photoactivity and photostability.[21a] The surface protected Cu2O achieved a photocurrent density of 7.5 mA cm−2 under AM 1.5 illumination, which was about three times higher than Cu2O without protection (Figure 12c,d). Furthermore, the protected electrodes remained photoactive after 1 h of testing and the measured Faradaic efficiency was close to 100% (Figure 12d). In contrast, bare Cu2O almost lost its photoactivity in first 20 minutes (Figure 12c). Later, Luo et al. reported the synthesis of Cu2O nanowire arrays on Cu-coated conductive fluorine-doped tin oxide substrates.[21b] The prepared Cu2O nanowire arrays were ALD coated with a 20 nm Al-doped ZnO (AZO) and a 100 nm TiO2 as protection overlayer, and followed by photo-deposition of a thin RuOx layer. The protected nanowire arrayed photocathodes delivered a high photocurrent densities of 10 mA cm−2 with a stable operation beyond 50 hour, which outperformed the best reported planar Cu2O for solar water splitting. Furthermore, carbon and metal oxide protecting layers prepared by chemical coating methods have also been reported, but they are less effective than the layers coated by ALD in protecting Cu2O from photocorrosion, possibly due to the low quality of the films with incompact protecting layer.[79]

At the applied voltage of −0.55 V vs Ag/AgCl in 1 m KOH solution, the CuO thin film photocathode achieved a maximum photocurrent of 1.2 mA cm−2 under light (AM 1.5G) illumination, which was corresponding to a solar conversion efficiency of 0.91%. Based on the surface protection studies on Cu2O, it is highly possible that CuO photocathode could also be stabilized by using similar ALD coating strategies and adding suitable catalysts.

sections.heading: 3.2. NiO and Co3O4
sections.text:
NiO is a p-type metal oxide that can be used as photocathode for PEC water reduction. However, the large bandgap (3.4 eV) of NiO significantly limits its efficiency for light absorption. Sensitization with dye or quantum dots has been commonly used as a strategy to improve the efficiency of NiO for PEC water reduction.[82] For example, Li et al. designed a p-type nanostructure NiO photocathode modified with both organic dye (P1) sensitizer and cobalt catalyst (Co1) for solar-assisted hydrogen generation (Figure 13a).[82c] The dye P1 was used for light harvesting, while Co1 was used as HER catalyst for hydrogen evolution. The cathode (NiO–P1–Co1) decorated with both photosensitizer P1 and catalyst Co1 showed a considerably higher photocurrent than the cathode modified only with P1 or Co1 (Figure 13b).[82c] Other dye sensitized NiO photocathodes have also been reported.[83] Although these results demonstrate that p-type nanostructure NiO photocathode sensitized with organic dye or catalyst can be employed as a photocathode for water reduction, the overall PEC performance is still relatively low. sections.heading: 3.3. Multinary Metal Oxides
sections.text:
In addition to the above-mentioned binary metal oxides, multinary metal oxides have also been widely studied as photocathodes for efficient hydrogen generation, such as CaFe2O4,[85] CuRhO2,[86] and CuFeO2.[87] In this section, we will briefly discuss the recent advancements of these multinary photocathode materials for solar hydrogen production.
Calcium iron oxide (CaFe2O4) is a p-type semiconductor with a narrow band gap of 1.9 eV. The conduction and valence band edges of CaFe2O4 are located at −0.6 and +1.3 V vs NHE respectively, which is suitable for water splitting.[85] CaFe2O4 as a photocathode material for hydrogen evolution was first reported by Matsumoto in 1987, however, it had a relatively low photoactivity due to the rapid recombination of photogenerated carriers in polycrystalline structure.[85a] Many studies have been carried out to solve this issue, such as structural improvement of CaFe2O4 by controlling synthesis process and metal doping.[88] Recently, Ida et al. prepared p-type CaFe2O4 film by a solution method followed by high temperature annealing. The prepared photocathode exhibited an excellent photocathodic current density of ≈1 mA cm−2 at −0.6 V vs Ag/AgCl for water reduction.[88b] Moreover, they also assembled a tandem
PEC cells with p-CaFe2O4 as cathode and n-TiO2 as anode electrode that can simultaneously generate hydrogen and oxygen gases under illumination. Furthermore, metal doping has been demonstrated an effective approach to improve the performance of CaFe2O4 for PEC water reduction. Sekizawa et al. reported various metal-doped p-type CaFe2O4 photocathodes with enhanced quantum efficiency.[85b,88c] CaFe2O4 and metal (e.g., Ag, Au, CuO, Pd and Ir) were co-deposited by radio frequency magnetron sputtering onto conducting antimony-doped tin oxide (ATO) glass substrate.[88c] Among these metal doped CaFe2O4 materials, Ag-
doped CaFe2O4 showed the highest photoactivity with a photocurrent at 0.0 V vs Ag/AgCl, which is 23 times higher than that of undoped CaFe2O4. CuRhO2 is another promising p-type metal oxide semiconductor with band edge positions straddling the electrolysis potentials, and thus it can be possibly used for direct PEC water splitting. Gu et al. synthesized a polycrystalline CuRhO2 by heating a stoichiometric amount of CuO and Rh2O3 at 850 °C.[86] The prepared CuRhO2 is a p-type polycrystalline material with a bandgap of 1.9 eV. Under visible light irradiation, it achieved an excellent photocurrent of −1.0 mA cm−2 at −0.9 V. IPCE studies indicated the visible light photoactivity of CuRhO2 can be extended to around 700 nm, suggesting the favorable bandgap for visible light absorption. Other multinary metal oxides have also been explored as photocathodes for water reduction. For example, Jang et al. synthesized CuFeO2 by hybrid microwave annealing (HMA).[87] The prepared CuFeO2 was further decorated with NiFe-layered double hydroxide/reduced graphene oxide. These photocathodes exhibited unprecedented high photoactivity of −2.4 mA cm−2 at 0.4 vs RHE in Ar saturated NaOH electrolyte under 1 sun illumination. Other multinary metal oxides such as CuBi2O4[89] and Rhdoped SrTiO3[90] were also identified as photocathode materials for solar water reduction. With engineered bandgaps and band edge potentials by combining multiple cations, multinary metal oxides are emerging as a new class of p-type semiconductor photocathodes for solar water reduction.

Metal oxide OER catalysts such as CoOx,[97] FeOOH,[52b,98] NiOOH[52b,99] have also been used to modify the surface of other photoanodes such as BiVO4.[23] Seabold et al. used photodeposition method to coat FeOOH catalyst on BiVO4 films.[98] The resulting BiVO4/FeOOH photoanode exhibited significantly improved photocurrent for photo-oxidation of water compared with bare BiVO4. Although OER catalyst could improve the PEC performance of photoanode, the overpotential for water oxidation is still relative large due to its four-electron process. Besides, metal oxide OER co-catalysts involve the changes of valence states during catalytic water oxidation process, too much loading amount of catalysts may introduce more capacitive current and the thick catalyst layers may also block light absorption efficiency of the photoanodes.[95,100] Therefore, improving the catalytic efficiency of metal oxide OER catalysts and lowering the loading amount is still a grand challenge.

Many metal oxides such as NiO and Co3O4 exhibit excellent OER performance, but their HER properties are not as good as their metal counterparts. However, some metal oxides such as ruthenium oxide are also known to be excellent catalysts for both water oxidation and reduction.[102] Tilley et al. used a photoelectrochemical deposition method to load RuOx catalyst on AZO/ TiO2 protected Cu2O photoelectrode for PEC water reduction.[13b] 40 nm thick RuOx catalyst layer was uniformly coated on the protection layer of AZO/TiO2 (Figure 15a). Figure 15b shows the first and subsequent photocurrent versus voltage sweeps collected for the sample. The first linear sweep yields a strong reduction photocurrent in the first three light chops that is attributed to the reduction of RuOx species to form active catalysts. After this activation process, the photocurrent onset potential of the RuOx modified AZO/TiO2 photocathode shifted to 0.55 V vs RHE (Figure 15c). Significantly, it achieved an excellent
plateau photocurrent density of 5 mA cm−2, which is just slightly smaller than the photocurrent obtained from a Pt modified photocathode. Additionally, RuOx modified photocathode showed excellent long term photostability, retaining 94% of activity after hours of continuous light irradiation (Figure 15d). These results prove that RuOx is an outstanding HER co-catalyst. However, Ruthenium is one of the least abundant elements on Earth, which makes it extremely challenging for large scale production. Other earth abundant and low cost metal oxides such as NiO and Co3O4 also showed promising HER catalytic performance, they are still far less effective than commonly used HER catalysts such as Pt and MoS2. Improving the performance of existing metal oxide HER catalysts and exploring new and inexpensive metal oxides for HER are very important.

For example, large bandgap metal oxide photoanodes such as TiO2 have suitable band edge potentials; however, the limited light absorption and large reaction overpotentials make it extremely difficult for direct water splitting. While small bandgap photocathodes such as silicon has suitable conduction band potentials for hydrogen evolution, the valence bands do not have enough oxidative powers for direct water oxidation. To this end, integration of photoanode and photocathode is necessary to achieve direct water splitting.[104] Alternatively, photoelectrodes can also couple with other devices to provide enough energy for water splitting. In this section, we will review the recent development of metal oxides based integrated devices for direct water splitting.

sections.heading: 5.1. Tandem Structures for Direct Water Splitting
sections.text:
Integrating photoanode and photocathode to form a tandem structure for conversion of solar energy into chemical fuel was first proposed by Nozik in 1977.[105] Later, Lewis et al. proposed an architecture structure composed of photoanode and photocathode nanowire arrays for direct solar water splitting in 2004 (Figure 16a).[106] The highly anisotropic nanowire array morphology decouples the long axis necessary for full absorption of light from the orthogonal (short) axis, which allows effective
charge transport and collection over short distances. OER and HER catalysts are decorated on photoanode and photocathode, respectively, to suppress the water splitting reaction overpotential. An ion exchange membrane employed provides the mechanical support for nanowires and benefits gas separation and safe operation of this system. With different bandgaps of photoanode and photocathode, the tandem structure can maximize light absorption of solar spectrum. With the help of surface band bending, the photoexcited electrons in photocathode migrate to the surface to reduce water and generate hydrogen; meanwhile, photoexcited holes in photoanode migrate to photoanode surface to oxidize water to produce O2. The holes from photocathode and electrons from photoanode will recombine at the Ohmic contact. As a result, two photons generated two pairs of electron and hole in this kind of integrated devices, but only one pair is used for water splitting.
In the past decade, this concept has also been extensively demonstrated in different material systems. For example Liu et al. reported a tandem structure by integrating Si nanowire photocathode and TiO2 nanowire photoanode (Figure 16b).[107] Pt and IrOx are used as HER and OER co-catalysts, respectively. In contrast to the device architecture proposed by Lewis et al., Liu et al. did not use ion exchange membrane.[107] Figure 16c-1 shows the current vs voltage curves of individual TiO2 nanowire arrayed photoanode and silicon nanowire photocathode. All metal oxide integration devices have also been demonstrated.[12d,109] For example, Mor et al. reported the integration of p-type Cu-Ti-O nanotube array photcathode with n-type TiO2 nanotube array photoanode. Vertically oriented p-type Cu-Ti-O nanotube arrays and n-type TiO2 nanotube arrays were fabricated by anodization of copper/titanium alloy film and titanium film which were co-sputtered onto the FTO glass substrates. sections.heading: 5.2. Integrating Metal Oxide PEC Cells with Other Devices for Direct Water Splitting
sections.text:
Integrating PEC cells with other energy conversion devices such as solar cells and microbial fuel cells is another promising approach to achieve unassisted solar water splitting.[110] PEC cells composed of a single photoelectrode typically require external bias (energy) to achieve direct water splitting or high solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency. This extra energy can be provided by other renewable energy sources. For example, Khaselev et al. demonstrated to use an integrated monolithic photoelectrochemical-photovoltaic design to achieve direct water electrolysis under visible light illumination.[110f,g] A high solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency of 12.4% was achieved under concentrated solar illumination on this system. However, the materials used in such devices are III-V semiconductors; the high cost and poor stability are the main limitations for these materials, which severely prevent its commercial application for PEC water splitting. The balance between device performance and fabrication cost is critical for economic production of solar hydrogen.
Metal oxide semiconductors based devices could significantly lower the cost and improve the device stability. For example, Brillet et al. employed a low cost dye sensitized solar cell (DSSC) in tandem with metal oxide photoanodes such as WO3 and Fe2O3 for direct water splitting under light irradiation.[111] Figure 18a shows the device structure and the device are stacked in a manner that light is incident on the photoanode. The individual device performance is critical and need optimization before integration. The IPCE and transmittance spectrum fit well with the bandgap of WO3 (Figure 18b). The large bandgap WO3 can only absorb photons with energy in ultraviolet to blue region, while the transmitted light will be absorbed by the dye sensitized solar cells. The device achieved a non-biased operation current of 2.35 mA cm−2, which corresponds to
solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency of 2.89% (Figure 18c). The gas generation by the integrated device and the generated hydrogen to oxygen ratio is around 2:1 (Figure 18d). For such device, front photoelectrode needs satisfy two requirements: high transparency and photocurrent density. To solve this problem, Shi et al. incorporated hybrid conductive distributed Bragg reflector (the dye/TiO2 electrode in the rear dye-sensitized solar cell) on the back side of the transparent conducting substrate for the front photoelectrochemical electrode (BiVO4/ WO3).[110g] The incident sunlight and the light reflected by the hybrid conductive Bragg reflector are mainly absorbed by the BiVO4/WO3 photoanode, while the solar irradiation with longer wavelength transmits through the photoanode is absorbed by the dye/TiO2 electrode. Through this way, a balance between light absorption and transmittance of the front PEC photoanodes was obtained and the device demonstrated an outstanding solar to hydrogen conversion efficiency up to 7.1%. Another way to solve the reflection problem was proposed by Qiu et al.[112] They deposited nanoporous Mo-doped BiVO4 on an engineered cone-shaped nanostructures with improved light absorption by multiple light scattering in the nanocone structures and achieved a solar to hydrogen conversion efficiency of 6.2%. The same device concept has also been applied to other metal oxide materials.[113]
Synergistic utilization of solar energy harvested by PEC cells and bio-energy generated by microbe were also developed for direct water splitting or hydrogen generation.[110d,e,114] Qian et al. demonstrated a solar-driven and self-biased microbial photoelectrochemical cell by coupling p-type Cu2O nanowire-arrayed photocathode with Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 as anodic inoculate for microbial electricity generation (Figure 19a).[110e] In microbial anode, Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 consume organic waste matters and release electrons. On the other hand, photoexcited electrons in Cu2O under light irradiation migrate to the surface of photocathode for water reduction to generate hydrogen and the photoexcited holes will combine with the electrons released by Shewanella oneidensis MR-1. sections.heading: 6. Challenges and Opportunities
sections.text:
In this article, we have reviewed the recent progress of using metal oxides for PEC water splitting. Although many metal oxide materials hold great potentials as photoelectrodes or catalysts, there are a number of challenges are remained to be addressed. For example, poor electrical conductivity and limited light absorption are still the main drawbacks of most metal oxides, when used as photoelectrodes for PEC water splitting. Although doping with foreign elements or self-defects has been developed to modify the optical and electronic properties of large bandgap metal oxides, the overall visible light photoactivity is still very low. Theoretical calculations have predicted that co-doping with anions and cations is an effective method to tune the electronic band structures of metal oxides for PEC water splitting, however, the experimental results are still far from satisfactory. We believe that the challenge is to improve the doping efficiency and have a good control on the dopant concentration and spatial distribution of dopants. A recent study showed that doping control is critical to improve the charge transport and PEC performance of hematite nanowires.[116] To achieve controlled doping in nanomaterials is known to be extremely difficult.[26a] It is particularly challenging to efficiently and controllably incorporate dopants with large ionic radius into the lattice of metal oxides. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop new doping methods. Ion implantation is a clean material processing technique, which can selectively incorporate any elements of interest into semiconductor electrode with controlled doses and depth. For example, this method can efficiently introduce atoms with large ionic radius into metal oxides and possibly to achieve any combination of co-doping systems, offering a versatile platform to experimentally investigate the effect of dopant, dopant concentration and distribution on their PEC performance and test the prediction from theoretical calculations. Additionally, it is also a promising way to combine various chemical modification strategies such as doping, SPR effect, heterojunctions and sensitization, and explore the possible synergistic effects to further push the PEC performance of metal oxides.[3a,30,32,117]
Besides improving the performance of the existing metal oxide semiconductors, searching new metal oxide materials with highly efficient photocatalytic activity is also of central importance for PEC water splitting. Combining multiple cations to form multi-ternary oxides has been found to be effective to modulate the bandgap and band edge positions. Moreover, multi-nary oxides such as perovskite structured metal oxides and solid solution metal oxides also have been demonstrated as effective photocatalysts for organic molecule decomposition and water splitting.[7,69,72,76a,118] However, these metal oxides have not been fully explored as photoelectrodes for PEC water splitting. We believe two issues may limit their performances as photoelectrodes. The first issue is the charge transport between particles as well as between particles and back contact. The diffusion length of majority carriers is expected to be much longer than that of metal oxide photocatalysts suspended in solution. In addition, the interfacial resistance and recombination loss can be significant limiting factors for their PEC performance. The second issue would be the electrical conductivity of multi-nary oxides, as most of them are not very conductive. New synthetic methods are required to synthesize monolith multi-nary metal oxide structures. Post-growth chemical modifications such as doping and defect engineering may also be required to enhance their electrical conductivities.

Additionally, cost-effective surface protection to prevent photoelectrode from photocorrosion is also very challenging. Atomic layer deposition is still the most- effective method to achieve the protection purpose, due to its controllable coating thickness and high coating quality without pinholes.[21a] However, the cost of surface coating by ALD is expensive and it is also impossible to achieve rapid and large scale preparation of surface protected photoelectrodes. Therefore, the development of low cost chemical coating strategies is extremely necessary to replace the current ALD method. Moreover, the coating materials are usually inert metal oxides such as TiO2 and AZO, resulting that oxygen evolution and hydrogen evolution reaction overpotentials on inert materials are usually very high and requiring HER or OER co-catalyst modification.[21a] However, the HER and OER performance of most low cost metal oxides are typically lower than the noble metals such as Pt and Ru. Creation of oxygen vacancies in Co3O4 or reduced Co3O4 has been demonstrate to be effective in improving their OER [13a] and HER performance.[119] Development of low cost metal oxides with highly efficient HER and OER properties to replace the noble and expensive Ru and Pt is also highly desirable.
Besides the studies on the photoelectrode materials, developing new in situ microscopy and spectroscopy techniques to understand the underlying mechanism of PEC water splitting represents a formidable challenge. It requires such techniques own high spatial and temporal resolution to probe the charge dynamics and reaction intermediates on the surface of photoelectrodes under operating conditions. In situ transient absorption spectroscopy has recently been employed to probe the charge carrier dynamics in PEC water splitting to provide the information on the yields of photogenerated charge carriers as well as the recombination, trapping/de-trapping of charge carriers and life-time of these processes.[120] The results are extremely useful in understanding the surface kinetics of metal oxide photoelectrodes. Furthermore, in situ infrared spectroscopy (IR) has been used to probe the water oxidation intermediates on the photoanode surface, by analyzing the light dependent absorption behavior of photoelectrodes.[121] In addition, synchrotron based X-ray spectroscopy has been employed as a powerful surface–sensitive tool to study the tiny structural change under light illumination and probe the active sites for the catalytic reactions.[122] In situ X-ray spectroscopy techniques can further provide important information on the evolution of chemical nature of metal oxide photoelectrodes/catalyst during water splitting reactions.[122] We believe the real time and in situ holistic studies of metal oxides for PEC water splitting are critical for understanding the reaction mechanism and it is the key to improve and optimize the PEC performance of metal oxide materials.
To achieve direct unassisted water splitting, integration device is an effective approach.[104] However, when coupling with other electrodes or devices, current matching need to be considered and the overall performance of the integrated devices is mainly limited by the part with low current. Currently, the photocurrent densities of photoanodes still cannot match with the most well-known silicon photocathode, and significantly limit the overall n-p tandem integration devices. Therefore, pushing the photoanode performance to make them match with photocathode is still highly important. Besides, coupling metal oxide semiconductors with bacterial is also
becoming an emerging research interest to simultaneously utilize solar energy and bio-energy to achieve clean fuel generation and environmental remediation.[115] The interdisciplinary studies could not only open up new opportunities to achieve sustainable and cost-effective water splitting, but also inspire to develop new devices which can employ the synergistic effect between solar energy with other kinds of energy forms such as wind, thermal and mechanical energy.[123]

metadata.abstractText: Rapid increase of global population has resulted in an evergrowing demand for energy. Seeking sustainable energy sources is becoming an emergent issue.[1] Hydrogen gas, with high gravimetric energy density (≈140 MJ kg−1) and zero carbon emission has been regarded as an encouraging and potential energy carrier to replace the conventional fossil fuels. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting is a promising and environmentally friendly method to obtain hydrogen gas in a sustainable manner.[2] Basically, PEC devices convert solar energy into chemical energy that stored in the form of dihydrogen molecules.[2b,e,3] The first report of a PEC cell for water splitting dates back to 1972.[3c] A conventional PEC cell is composed of at least one photoelectrode responsible for harvesting Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting represents an environmentally friendly and sustainable method to obtain hydrogen fuel. Semiconductor materials as the central components in PEC water splitting cells have decisive influences on the device’s solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency. Among semiconductors, metal oxides have received a lot of attention due to their outstanding (photo)-electrochemical stability, low cost, favorable band edge positions and wide distribution of bandgaps. In the past decades, significant processes have been made in developing metal oxide nanomaterials for PEC water splitting. In this review, the recent progress using metal oxides as photoelectrodes and co-catalysts for PEC water splitting is summarized. Their performance, limitations and potentials are also discussed. Last, the key challenges and opportunities in the development and implementation of metal oxide nanomaterials for PEC water splitting are discussed. Water Splitting
